text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

All right, I'm
Victoria Ivashina.

I'm the faculty chair for
the MENA Research Center.

I have been doing
this since 2018,
and it's been my pleasure.
So what does faculty chair do?

And I see my role
as an intermediary.

Of course, one of the
primary roles of the center
is case writing.

And there are
several other things

that involve interacting
with students and alums.

And while our general mission
is education, faculty of course

is often the ones who leads
this mission unavoidably.

And so, I see my
role as a person

who provides a context or
facilitates understanding, what

are the priorities
at the school, how

those priorities
are articulated,

and just generally
understanding and helping

with the communication
with the school.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hi.

I'm Victoria Winston, executive
director of the Global
Initiative at HBS.

When we opened the Middle
East North Africa Research

Center, or the
MENARC, in 2013, there

was something very
different about it

from the other seven
centers that HBS had already
established around the globe.

In choosing past locations,
we'd gone to geographies

where our faculty already
had a deep knowledge

and a deep interest
and where it was simply

thought to be more
efficient to satisfying

that interest by building a
small staff of researchers
to facilitate it.

But with the MENARC,
our dean Nitin Nohria

wanted to take an entirely
different approach.

He wanted to identify a
region where our faculty had

less knowledge and
expertise, but a region

that was so important to the
world's economy and business

that developing that
knowledge and bringing it back

into our classroom
and onto our campus
was thought to be paramount.

It was with this in mind
that we recruited Esel Cekin,

tasking her to create
and stimulate demand
and interest in the region.

And needless to say, in
10 short years, the MENARC

has been very successful in
meeting those objectives,

and I am confident they
will continue to do so.

It's been my personal
pleasure to have
been a part of this journey.
Thank you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hi.

I'm Alpana Thapar, and
I'm the executive director

of the Middle East and North
Africa Research Center.

And I invite you to join us
in celebrating our 10th year
anniversary.

Our presence in the region
started in Istanbul in 2013
by Esel Cekin.

Under the Istanbul
Research Center.

Part of the Global
Initiative, the center

focused on facilitating
faculty research

as well as offering
programmatic support.

As we gradually widened our
reach within the region,

we transitioned to becoming the
MENA Research Center in 2015,

and we opened an
office in Dubai.

In June 2016, I began
my journey at the center

helping to deepen relationships
within the local business

communities and to support areas
like the school's MBA admission

efforts, student programming,
and executive education
in the region.

In the spring of last year,
we opened our office in Cairo.

Over time, our team
grew, and today we

have seven members spread across
Dubai, Cairo, and Istanbul.

I'm proud to share
that we've developed

over 150 cases covering
12 countries with close
to 80 faculty members.

We are very thankful to all
the friends of the center who

have been part of our
journey, and we look forward

to playing a meaningful role
in contributing to the school's
global strategy and research.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The MENA Research
Center was instrumental

in the Global Experience
office's ability

to run successful
field global immersion

programs in both Istanbul
and Casablanca this past May.

Between working with
our team to establish

12 global partners in
each of those cities

to arranging some incredibly
unique opportunities

for our students on the
ground during the immersion,

we are so thankful
for your partnership,

and I look forward to working
together in future years.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hi.

I'm Skip Nordhoff from the
Office of External Relations.

It's been my great pleasure
over the last 10 years

to be able to work with the
Middle East North Africa

Research Center, first
under the leadership of Esel

and now with Alpana
leading the team.

It's been an absolute
pleasure to be

able to work with and
partner with alumni

across the region from
Istanbul through the Gulf

and the Levant, to
travel to the region

and to help support the
important work of faculty,

students, and staff
who are working
in this very important region.

And of course, to our alumni
who give of their time, talent,

and treasure, we're
extremely grateful to you.

It's only because of you that
we're able to do this work.

And also, again, to Alpana
and the team in Dubai,

in Istanbul, in Cairo,
and across the region,

we're extremely
grateful for your work.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

My name is Stephane
Sinimale, and I'm
part of HBS executive education.

As a regional director
for the school,

my role consists of developing
key client relationships

in a territory comprising the
Middle East, Africa, Turkey,
and Switzerland.

The close partnership
with our Istanbul office

allows us to keep a close
pulse on the economic activity,

identify new prospect
company leads,

and support the
planning and logistics
of my regular Istanbul visits.

On a more strategic
level, the Research Center

has also been an
invaluable partner.

When in 2017 we launched a new
alumni granting status program,

HBS Senior Executive
Leadership Program Middle East.

This four-modules program
spread over a 10-month period

had initially a limited
number of regional cases.

Thanks to our faculty
coming to the regions

and engaging with the
SELPME participants

and their sponsoring
companies, the Research Center

has contributed
to the development

of additional cases,
which in turn enriched

our ever-growing
collections of global cases.

On behalf of our
executive education team,

I would like to once
again share our gratitude

for the productive and
mutually rewarding journey

and look forward to many more
opportunities to collaborate.
Thank you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hey, everyone.

My name is Vai
Schierholtz, and I'm

the director of marketing
within MBA Admissions at HBS.

On behalf of the
entire admissions team,

I want to congratulate
the MENA Research Center
on its 10th-year anniversary.

From helping
Admissions host events

in the region to getting
admits to say yes to HBS,

we couldn't be more thankful
for such a great partner who

will help us build the next
class of leaders who will
make a difference in the world.

10 years is an amazing
accomplishment,

and we're so grateful for
the work you do for HBS.

Here's to 10 more
exciting years.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
